question_details.title: Will the following companies be added to the S&P 500 before October 2025? (ARES)
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2025-07-24 20:00:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/38681). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

The [S\&P 500 Index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%26P_500) is a stock market index that measures the stock performance of 500 large companies listed on stock exchanges in the United States. The index is maintained by [S\&P Dow Jones Indices](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%26P_Dow_Jones_Indices), and inclusion decisions are based on factors such as market capitalization, liquidity, financial viability, and sector representation. Current index constituents can be viewed [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_S%26P_500_companies#S\&P_500_component_stocks).

S\&P 500 membership is valued by corporations because it indicates success and boosts brand awareness.

To join S\&P 500 a company must fulfill the following requirements:

* It must have a market capitalization of at least \$20.5 billion.
* It must be domiciled in the U.S.
* It must be a corporation whose shares are listed on an exchange, such as the New York Stock Exchange, the Nasdaq system, or one of the CBOE exchanges.
* It can not be a limited partnership, master limited partnership, closed-end fund, limited liability company, special purpose acquisition company, or SPAC.

Five possible candidates to be added to the S\&P 500 in over the following months are:

* [ARES (Ares Management Corporation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ares_Management): A global alternative investment firm specializing in credit, private equity, real estate, and infrastructure assets.
* [MSTR (MicroStrategy Incorporated)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MicroStrategy): A business analytics company known for significant investments in Bitcoin as part of its corporate treasury strategy.
* [TTD (The Trade Desk, Inc.)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Trade_Desk): A technology company providing a platform for data-driven digital advertising management and optimization.
* [HOOD (Robinhood Markets, Inc.)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robinhood_Markets): A widely recognized fintech firm with significant retail investor engagement and growing product diversification.
* [DDOG (Datadog, Inc.)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Datadog): A cloud-native monitoring and analytics platform that has shown strong growth and relevance in enterprise infrastructure.

question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question is a subquestion of a group question. This subquestion specifically targets the option 'ARES'. The resolution criteria for the parent question is below. 

Each subquestion will resolve as **Yes** if the corresponding company is announced to be officially added to the S\&P 500 Index before October 1, 2025, according to [S\&P Dow Jones Indices](https://www.spglobal.com/).
question_details.fine_print:
* Subquestions will resolve based on official announcements from S\&P Dow Jones Indices that a company will be added. The actual inclusion of the company to the index is not required for resolution.
* Potential retractions or cancellations of an inclusion announcement will not affect the resolution of subquestions.

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Strategy's (MSTR) S&P 500 Snub Signals Chill for Corporate Bitcoin (BTC) Treasuries: JPMorgan**
JPMorgan’s analyst report notes that Strategy’s (MSTR) bid to join the S&P 500 was rejected even though it met all technical eligibility criteria, a move the bank says signals growing caution toward companies that function as de‑facto bitcoin funds. The decision is a setback not only for Strategy but for the broader cohort of corporate crypto treasuries that use balance‑sheet bitcoin accumulation. The report points out that Strategy’s inclusion in other major benchmarks—such as the Nasdaq 100 and MSCI indices—has quietly given bitcoin a backdoor into retail and institutional portfolios. JPMorgan warns that the S&P 500 decision could mark the limit of that trend and may prompt other index providers to rethink the inclusion of bitcoin‑heavy companies. Adding to the pressure, Nasdaq has reportedly begun requiring shareholder approval before companies can issue new stock to buy crypto. Strategy recently abandoned its no‑dilution pledge, indicating a willingness to issue shares at lower multiples to continue funding bitcoin purchases. Corporate crypto treasuries are facing weakening share prices and slowing issuance; equity and debt fundraising volumes declined last quarter, suggesting investor appetite is waning. The rising risk premium could push investors and index providers to favor crypto companies with operating businesses—such as exchanges and miners—over pure bitcoin‑holding vehicles. The report cites bitcoin’s price at $108,783.53 and notes that the S&P 500 decision could "mark the limit of that trend" and that "the rising risk premium could push investors and index providers to favor crypto companies with operating businesses, like exchanges and miners, over pure bitcoin‑holding vehicles."
Original language: en
Publish date: September 11, 2025 11:58 AM
Source:[CoinDesk](https://www.coindesk.com/markets/2025/09/11/strategy-s-s-and-p-500-snub-is-a-cautionary-signal-for-corporate-bitcoin-treasuries-jpmorgan)

**S&P 500 Rejects Strategy Despite Meeting Eligibility Criteria, JPMorgan Reports**
The S&P 500 index committee rejected Strategy (formerly MicroStrategy) from the index last week, even though the company met all technical eligibility criteria. JPMorgan analysts, led by managing director Nikolaos Panigirtzoglou, described the move as a "blow to crypto treasuries" and warned that it signals caution toward firms that function primarily as bitcoin funds. The decision affects not only Strategy but also other crypto‑treasury companies that have emerged recently. Strategy, the largest public crypto‑treasury firm, had previously been included in major benchmarks such as the Nasdaq 100, MSCI USA, MSCI World and the Russell 2000, which had helped drive its stock performance. The rejection suggests that the indirect channel for bitcoin exposure through index inclusion may be "reaching its limits," according to the JPMorgan report. The article notes that other index providers might reconsider adding similar firms after the S&P 500’s lead, potentially restricting their access to broader investment portfolios. Additional pressures include Nasdaq’s new requirement for shareholder approval before issuing shares to fund crypto purchases, and a recent shift by Strategy away from a pledge to avoid issuing shares below a 2.5‑multiple. Market fatigue is evident in declining equity issuance volumes and slowing funding activity for crypto‑treasury firms, while debt issuance continues with higher risk premiums. JPMorgan analysts warn that skepticism toward bitcoin‑backed loans, token‑linked convertibles and other structured financing is growing, and that capital may shift toward crypto companies with operating businesses such as exchanges and miners. The S&P 500 rejection reflects broader market concerns about companies whose primary business model revolves around holding cryptocurrency rather than traditional operations, and could reshape how crypto‑focused companies structure their balance sheets moving forward.
Original language: en-US
Publish date: September 11, 2025 09:55 AM
Source:[Blockonomi](https://blockonomi.com/sp-500-rejects-strategy-despite-meeting-eligibility-criteria-jpmorgan-reports/)

**Part of the Club: Robinhood & AppLovin Soar on S&P 500 Inclusion**
The article reports that on September 8, 2025, Robinhood Markets (NASDAQ: HOOD) and AppLovin (NASDAQ: APP) were added to the S&P 500 Index, a move that validates their business fundamentals and is expected to drive further share demand.  At the time of inclusion, Robinhood had a market capitalization of $33 billion and AppLovin $109 billion; about 25 % of S&P 500 constituents began 2025 with lower market caps, making the addition seem inevitable.  Shares reacted strongly: Robinhood closed up nearly 16 % and AppLovin rose almost 12 %.  Prior to the price action, both stocks had surged 496 % and 520 % over the previous 52 weeks, respectively, but the article notes that such gains are not solely speculative.  S&P requires a positive GAAP net income over the last 12 months; Robinhood has maintained positive GAAP net income for seven consecutive quarters, while AppLovin has done so for nine quarters, underscoring their profitability.  In contrast, Bitcoin‑buyer Strategy (NASDAQ: MSTR) – which also meets the market‑cap threshold of $22.7 billion – has shown positive GAAP net income only two of eight quarters, making it a less likely candidate for inclusion.  The article explains that passive funds such as BlackRock’s iShares Core S&P 500 ETF (NYSEARCA: IVV), which holds roughly $667 billion in net assets, will need to purchase the new constituents to track the index, creating additional buying pressure.  Active managers may also adjust their holdings toward the new index weights, further supporting demand.  Overall, the article presents the inclusion as a credibility boost for the companies, while noting that long‑term success will still depend on continued earnings growth and business expansion.

Publish date: September 10, 2025 06:31 PM
Source:[Market Beat](https://www.marketbeat.com/originals/part-of-the-club-robinhood-and-applovin-soar-on-s-and-p-500-inclusion/)

**Strategy Misses S&P 500 Inclusion This Month: Will It Ever Make the Cut?**
Strategy (MSTR), the world’s largest corporate holder of Bitcoin, was omitted from the S&P 500 during the latest quarterly rebalancing, with AppLovin (APP), Robinhood (HOOD) and Emcor (EME) added instead. The company meets all eligibility criteria—U.S. domicile, a market capitalization above $22.7 billion, profitability in the most recent quarter and year, and at least 50 % of shares publicly available—but the Index Committee also weighs sector weighting and other factors. Bloomberg ETF analyst James Seyffart estimates that $22 trillion is linked to S&P‑500‑based products, and Stephens analysis says fund managers would need to buy roughly 50 million Strategy shares worth about $16 billion if the firm were added. After reporting a $10 billion profit in the last quarter, Strategy still fell short of inclusion. Former committee chair David Blitzer told Bloomberg that the committee’s goal is ‘to have an index that really is a great measure of the market.’ He added, ‘The market goes up, the index goes up. Any statistics about the market, you can do the same calculation on the index and you’ll be very close.’

**Robinhood Enters S&P 500, Marking Retail Trading's Shift To Wall Street Core - AppLovin (NASDAQ:APP), Acadia Healthcare Co (NASDAQ:ACHC)**
S&P Dow Jones Indices announced a quarterly rebalance that will take effect before markets open on September 22. The update adds AppLovin Corp. (APP), Robinhood Markets Inc. (HOOD), and Emcor Group Inc. (EME) to the S&P 500, replacing MarketAxess Holdings (MKTX), Caesars Entertainment (CZR), and Enphase Energy (ENPH), which will move to smaller‑cap indexes. summary:
Forecasters assessing the likelihood of Ares Management (ARES) being announced as an addition to the S&P 500 before October 2025 broadly agree that the company meets all technical criteria for inclusion—market capitalization, profitability, liquidity, US domicile, and a straightforward corporate structure. Several experts view ARES as a textbook candidate: large, profitable, established, and in a sector that has recently seen similar firms (e.g., Blackstone, Apollo) added to the index. The main reasons increasing ARES's probability are its strong, recurring GAAP profitability, sectoral relevance as an alternative asset manager with growing economic importance, and absence of negative news or disqualifying issues.

However, all experts emphasize the key role of the S&P 500 Index Committee's discretion. Even among highly eligible companies, committee decisions are influenced by sector representation, index turnover rates, recent rebalancing activity, and broader market or regulatory considerations. The recent exclusion of technically qualified companies (e.g., MicroStrategy) underscores that meeting eligibility is not sufficient; the committee also weighs risk, stability, and strategic sector objectives. Some experts note the slow turnover rate in the index, with only a handful of new additions each year, and competition from other strong candidates that may be prioritized for sectoral or thematic reasons.

Consensus scenarios for a 'Yes' outcome involve a current S&P 500 constituent (especially in financials) being removed, creating an opening that the committee fills with ARES due to its strong fundamentals and sector fit. A 'No' scenario arises if sector representation is already sufficient, few or no removals occur, or the committee opts to diversify the index with candidates from other sectors instead.

Probability estimates vary significantly by perspective: the most cautious, accounting-focused forecasters (emphasizing base rates and committee conservatism) estimate an 18–23% chance. Most finance and equity research experts, weighing ARES's strong profile against moderate turnover and discretionary risk, assign probabilities of 30–35%. Strategic management and resource-based experts, who emphasize recent committee openness to alternative asset managers and ARES's strong competitive position, estimate much higher probabilities—65–85%—contingent on the absence of negative shocks and a slot opening during index maintenance.

In sum, ARES is widely viewed as a highly qualified, likely-in-line candidate, but the unpredictability of S&P 500 committee decisions, limited turnover, and sector balancing reduce overall confidence. The distribution of estimates illustrates a substantial (though uncertain) chance of inclusion, contingent on external events and evolving committee priorities.
